moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7
comment: It was only here that I looked up the theory and learned that 12.Nxf7 was a move... it seemed more interesting than any of the alternatives so I just played it. I figured that since Svidler had played it once against Anand it couldn't be too bad, so I would just go where the currents took me and figure things out as I went. It turned out that this led to a very interesting struggle.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4
comment: Before I played this I had got around to studying the position myself and I decided I liked this move better than Svidler's approach. 14.Ne4 is natural; it clears the way for the c1-bishop, the f-pawn, and it has some less obvious points as well.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4
comment: Since the c1-bishop is unleashed black cannot meet 16. Qg4+ anymore with 16...Ke7. Therefore, the main threat is Qg4+, Qf5+, and e5-e6, when there is a mate threat to f7 and the bishop on d5 suddenly hangs. Black's move 15...Ne7 seems like the only way to meet this threat tactically, but since it involves backing up, burying the f8-bishop and leaving the king in the center, I ought to have good compensation for the piece.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+
comment: This is an important intermezzo that might not be so easy to spot over the board. I didn't see what would happen but I saw that I had to play it or else I would lose my compensation for the piece, so I was still flowing with the current...

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4
comment: 19.f4 immediately might be possible, but it seemed obvious to play this first. The tactical idea is just that if black leaves the diagonal then Qf3+ picks up a rook. c6 is apparently a worse square for the queen because she is actually well-placed in a centralised position; for example f4-f5 is met by just ...Qxe5. However in the game there is another important consideration that comes out; from c6 the queen makes a defense possible with ...Ng6, so 19.c4 may have actually helped black.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4
comment: Playing this before ...Qc6 avoids cxb5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4
comment: Frankly this was the only move I considered since it seemed positionally sound to push the passers ahead. Black has some serious problems to unravel before I play f5-f6 or else he will be losing ... frankly I didn't see how he could do it. If I had appreciated the strength of ...Ng6 then I might have considered grabbing another pawn here with 21.Qxd4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6
comment: Black has a well thought out defense. This move gains a tempo because of my 24th move.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6
comment: Nice, intending to meet f4-f5 with ...Nxe5. Qf5+ seems like it ought to be disruptive but it doesn't do anything and gets in the way of my pawns.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5
comment: During the game I was more worried about how to get compensation after 24...Be7, and probably justifiably. Although 24...Bc5 seems logical, it is probably a mistake if black cannot find any improvements on the game and 38.Rf5 is as strong as it appears.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3
comment: It was only in this position that I finally found some tactical ways to get back the material... I was ecstatic, surely this must mean I am winning? If I can get back material, and retain my attack?! 30.Qd3 is not the most obviously agressive move but it threatens f5-f6 and Qg6, and stops defenses based on d4-d3+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6
comment: This seems like the best defense from black yet again, although it returns the material.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6
comment: Forced, to gain control of the g3-square.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5
comment: Opening the a2-g8 diagonal with tempo.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6
comment: This is what I had seen at move thirty, which had convinced me I was finally winning. But, black doesn't take the rook and his position turns out to be very resiliant.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4
comment: This is the obvious move; white keeps the attack going. The next several moves of black are forced.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4 Rxe7 35. Re6 Rf7 36. f6 d3
comment: Absolutely forced. The d-pawn is a diversion to white's attack as it starts threatening to promote. Equally importantly, black gets the simple defense to 38.Qe6+ of 38...Qb6+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4 Rxe7 35. Re6 Rf7 36. f6 d3 37. Re8+ Bf8 38. Rd8
comment: Only after the game, analysing with Fritz, I finally found what is apparently the winning continuation, 38.Rf5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4 Rxe7 35. Re6 Rf7 36. f6 d3 37. Re8+ Bf8 38. Rd8 Rh6 39. fxg7
comment: Intuitively it seems completely wrong to expose my king to discovery and let black take over the initiative. However, my investigations of 39.Rxd3 did not reveal any clear way to play for the win without running the risk of just being down material. Therefore I looked more closely at 39.fxg7, and when I decided that black only had a draw, I just played it.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4 Rxe7 35. Re6 Rf7 36. f6 d3 37. Re8+ Bf8 38. Rd8 Rh6 39. fxg7 Rxf1+ 40. Kxf1 d2+ 41. Kf2 Kxg7
comment: Now white is completely safe because he recovers the d-pawn, but there was nothing better.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Nbd2 Nc5 10. c3 d4 11. Ng5 Bd5 12. Nxf7 Kxf7 13. Qf3+ Ke6 14. Ne4 Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Ne7 16. Bg5 Bxb3 17. Qg4+ Kf7 18. axb3 Qd5 19. c4 bxc4 20. bxc4 Qc6 21. f4 h6 22. Bh4 h5 23. Qh3 Ng6 24. Bg5 Bc5 25. e6+ Kg8 26. f5 Nf8 27. Rae1 Nh7 28. Bh4 Rf8 29. e7 Re8 30. Qd3 Nf6 31. Re6 Bd6 32. c5 Qxc5 33. Rxf6 Qb5 34. Qe4 Rxe7 35. Re6 Rf7 36. f6 d3 37. Re8+ Bf8 38. Rd8 Rh6 39. fxg7 Rxf1+ 40. Kxf1 d2+ 41. Kf2 Kxg7 42. Qd4+ Kg8 43. Qxd2 Qf5+ 44. Kg1 Rd6 45. Qg5+
comment: Here I offered a draw which was accepted. This allowed me to focus on another game against the same opponent, where I was a pawn down but yet seemed completely defensible as long as my approach was well thought out. I am happy to report I succeeded in drawing it.
